RHD-125
New York City,
November 17, 1905.
Mr. John G. Neihardt,
Bancroft, Nebraska.
My dear Neihardt:
div1.p: "Myrrh" received. A cursory inspection of a few of the verses leads me to the impression that parts of it ought to be fumigated. I know that warm, passionate nature of yours is difficult to suppress, but I think you had a tremendous gall to send this through the United States Mail.

Nevertheless, it has the true Swinburnian touch here and there, and, in future years, when you have passed away and the Omaha Indians are decorating your grave with poppies and butter-cups, some passing stranger will scatter white rose leaves across your tomb.

I mean by this, that your fame will probably arrive at a moment when you are not present to enjoy it. Poetry at its best is a difficult thing, but I am going to make a conscientious effort to place this with some publisher with courage enough to print it.
Are you a married man? I suspect not, or you would not have written some of the lines to that invisible, fugitive thing called "woman."

Mr. Dooley says that a hero is a man who buys steel common when it is selling at .58, but my private opinion is
7 Mr. John G. Neihardt, ----------RHD-126.
that a hero is a man who writes poetry when it is not selling at all.
Your lines — "If This Be Sin" and "Let Down Your Hair" look like the real thing to me.
However, I am interested in any man, friendly to the Indians, and I will do the best I can. Some day this week I will read the work through.
By all means get two or three Indian authorities to drop us a line, and I will see that they are properly utilized.

Have you ever thought of writing a serial — a serial novel — running, say, between 40,000 and 60,000 words? I should think something strong could be turned out in your neck of the woods, with the re-habilitated Indians as a back-ground. If you are interested in the idea, I would be pleased if you would send me a brief scenario of any plot that may come tumbling into your head. Somehow or other, I think you are going to write a pretty good yarn sooner or later, about these people, and I want to be the first to read it, —— also, you are a cordial party, the same which is scarce even in the Kingdom of Heaven.
